Councilwoman Sussman, Dr. Sussman, please read Proclamation 3.13.
Thank you, Mr. President.
In honor of women's history month, I am very proud to be bringing forth this proclamation.
Honoring Denver's Women First Responders.

Whereas Women's History Month designation traces back to the first International Women's
Day in 1911.

In February 1980, President Jimmy Carter made a presidential proclamation declaring the
week of March 8th National Women's History Week, stating that too often women's
contributions to American society were unsung and unnoticed.

And whereas the City and County of Denver has a rich history of women serving as members
of the Denver Police Department, the Denver Sheriff's Department, and the Denver Fire
Department.

And whereas the women of the Denver Police Department contract their history back to the
1880s with police matrons Sadie Likens, who oversaw female and juvenile prisoners in the
city jail.
Margaret Conway led efforts to prevent human trafficking in the 1920s.

Josephine Roche started her public service career in 1912 as a Denver Police Officer,
Grand for Governor, and went on to serve as Assistant Secretary to the Treasury under
Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

Women officers finally joined their male counterparts in patrolling the streets of Denver
in the 1970s.

And whereas the women of the Denver Sheriff's Department contract their history to Aurora
Quinn, who has appointed a Denver Deputy Sheriff and served from 1902 to 1922.

Quinn was the first female probation officer in the state of Colorado, as well as one of
the earliest female Deputy Sheriffs in the United States.
The celebrated Ida Younger started her career as a uniformed Denver Deputy in 1958.

In 2007, Marie Kyler became the first female Division Chief overseeing the Downtown
Detention Center and Support Services.

And whereas the women of the Denver Fire Department contract their history to the Early
Women's Fire Auxiliary, Heather Larson joined the department as the first active female
firefighter in 1985.
In 2009, Angela Cook became the first woman Division Chief overseeing operations at DIA.

Early this year, Twania Clark became the first African American female engineer in the
150-year history of the department.

Most recently, on March 7th, newly appointed Assistant Chief Carly Helwick was the first
chief to respond to the three alarm blaze at 1833 Emerson, directing the efforts of the
firefighters battling that tragic blaze.

And whereas the women first responders of Denver have served, protected, and saved
countless lives in the city and county of Denver, while showing leadership, courage, and
strength in the line of duty, they are our trailblazers and our role models.

Now, therefore, be it proclaimed by the council, the city and county of Denver, that the
council hereby recognizes and thanks the hundreds of women who have served our community
as members of the Denver Police Department, the Denver Sheriff Department, and the Denver
Fire Department.

And section two, that the clerk of the city and county of Denver shall attest and affix
the seal of the city and county of Denver to this proclamation and that a copy be
delivered to the Denver Police Department, the Denver Sheriff Department, and the Denver
Fire Department.
Your motion to adopt?
I move that we adopt this proclamation.
All right.
It has been moved and seconded comments by members of council, Dr. Sussman.

Well, I can't tell you how proud I am to have all these wonderful women in the audience
and to be asked to give such a proclamation.

It has been a wonderful experience just learning the history of the Denver Fire
Department, the Police Department, and the Sheriff Department.

And of the number of women who did things long ago and those who have done them most
recently to help protect our city, to help protect our citizens and everything that you
have done in your lives to serve the community, to serve all of us.

I was able to talk just a little bit with some of you beforehand and it's just inspiring
to have you here.

I urge my fellow colleagues to please vote for this proclamation for the proudness we feel
for the women of these departments.
Thank you, Dr. Sussman.
Councilwoman Black.
Thank you, Mr. President.

I wanted to thank you all for your service and your leadership and for being role models
for all of the women and girls.
And please add my name as a sponsor.
Thank you.
We will add it.

Thank you, Mr. President.
I want to add my two cents on this proclamation as well.

I can remember, I'm not sure if it was when I was serving as a staff member or after I had
gotten elected as a council member.

And this was, gosh, quite a few years ago, and folks in the city were asking if I was
stepping down from serving in office or if I was trying to be on the fire department, I
said, no, I'm just trying to audit the process because we don't have very many women who
have gotten on the department.
And I want to understand what the challenge and what the problem is.

So needless to say, I didn't go through the whole process, but it was an interesting
endeavor.

And to see that we have so many more women in all three units, the sheriff's department,
the police department and the fire department.
And see you all sitting in the audience here tonight.

I know you're not representative of all the women in those three units, but I want to
thank you all for your service.

My daughter is among our women in uniform that serve within our department and very proud
of the work that she and each one of you do every day in representing our city and doing
the best job that you can.
And I just want to say I'm proud of each one of you for the work that you do for our city.

You know, people get to see you as you're out in the public and you're a reflection of all
of us.

And I know that we have the utmost dedication and professionalism among folks in our
department.
And just want to say thank you for the work you do every day and day out.
Thank you.
Thank you, Councilor Artega.
Councilor Lopez.
Thank you, Mr. President.
Thank you, Mr. President.
Thank you, Councilwoman Sussman for bringing the proclamation forward.
Thank you all for your service, and I just wanted to express my gratitude.
You know, I think we don't know.

I mean, occasionally you'll get one of the council members to do a ride along or come to
roll call or anything like that, but really to really know the work that you all put in is
hard work.

Especially when you're in service and you have a badge like you do, either on your

That city seal means something.
That's all of us, right?

And when I see this room, I see officers, I see deputies, I see firefighters, I see civil
servants.
Who happen to be women?
But you all represent the everything that I try to teach my daughter to see, right?

And I've always believed, and I think I'm not the only person that said this before, but
you can't be what you can't see.
And there's something to be said about you all being seen.

I see you in the community, our kids see you in the community, our community members see

And, you know, I got to say this, Councilman Artega is being very humble.
Her own daughter is a deputy.

And to see, and I passed Councilman Artega a picture that I took, because I caught it, she

And to see the eyes at Councilman Artega, just that pride.

When she looked upon her daughter getting that commendation, that picture, I took that

I was like a teenage boy with people with camera, right?
And it's the same look that I see in our community when they see you all, right?
In this courthouse, in the fire station, or on patrol.
And I just wanted to express that to you.
I've never been able to say that to the group, but there it is.
In ten years, I wanted to express that gratitude.
I see that.
So, thank you.
Thank you, Councilman Lopez.
Councilman Espinosa.
Yeah, I too want to thank Councilwoman Sussman for bringing this up for recognition.

The one problem that I sort of had in listening to that proclamation was the gap between

And so, I think that that's amazing to me because if I think back to just my entire life,
especially, you know, when I grew up, my first responders were always females.
My grandmother and my mom.
And there was no ageism.
There was no concern about gender.

That's the person I wanted there first, when I hurt myself, when I felt scared, when I
needed that sense of security.
And always exceeded expectations.

And so, without, so I just want to say that gap, I'm glad to see we're making inroads, but

So, I just want to thank you all for your personal perseverance and the perseverance that
you represent over time.
And so, thank you all for your commitment to the city.
Both past and present.
Really appreciate you all for being here tonight.
Thanks.
All right, Councilwoman Kanique.
Thank you, Mr. President.
I won't echo this at well.

I echo the appreciation shared by my colleagues, but I thought it would be nice to just
comment a little bit on why I think your participation in our departments is so important.
You've had to overcome many stereotypes, I think, about women.

And I remember learning about the first female police officers and them having to conduct
business in high heels, for example, because the uniform required a skirt in high heels.
And so, we, in these agencies, so often focus on strength, right?

It's about a gun, it's about a piece of equipment, whether it be firefighting equipment or
driving a truck.

And I think because of the protector image being such a physical one, you know, that was
one of the major stereotypes.

One of the major stereotypes that women had to overcome, and I know in all of your
academies, you all have to meet these rigorous standards.
And we know that women can meet men as equals in terms of physical abilities.
But the research shows that women bring different problem solving skills to the job.
And I think modern law enforcement and fire protection are so much more aware of that.

And for example, our police department, you know, we think about training our police so
much more in problem solving and de-escalation, which involves listening.

And it involves the kind of empathy that, you know, someone who's in crisis might be able
to hear.
And I, you know, we don't want to reinforce stereotypes.
It's not that all women are good at that, all men are bad.

But the research demonstrates that when you bring women into a workplace, some of those
types of skills are strengthened in the team.

You know, I think about the firefighting team and, you know, anyone who's ever kind of
watched those four person teams and how they have to operate, having women and team work,
right, in terms of communication can subtly change the workplace in ways that help keep us
all safer.

And I think that is one of the things I most appreciate and why I think we need to
continue to strive to bring more women into our safety departments because those skills
aren't, it's not just that women are doing as good or the same job.

It's that they bring perhaps subtle enhancements to these agencies, whether it be police
or sheriff or fire, that are really important to us.
And so that research, I think, is really clear.

And so I appreciate not just the ways that you compete in the same realm that you do with
some of your male colleagues to get into these very competitive positions, but also the
unique skills that many of you probably bring to the teams you're a part of.
So thank you very much.
And let's keep recruiting a more next generation.
Thank you.
